docs.snippet: Google begins to pull back the curtain on its data centers to tout their energy efficiency....
docs.lead_paragraph: Google is many things: the most used Internet search engine, the largest seller of online advertising, the busiest online video site (YouTube), a maker of maps, e-mail and scores of other applications delivered over the Web. And all these things are possible because, first and foremost, Google is an immense collection of electricity-hungry data centers, packed with hundreds of thousands of computers that deliver all these digital services almost instantly to virtually any computer around the globe.

headline.main: Google Boasts of Its Energy-Efficient Data Centers

docs.abstract: Google begins to pull back the curtain on its data centers to tout their energy efficiency.

docs.snippet: History | For its 10th birthday, Google offers a way to look back at Web history using its 2001 page index (the earliest index accessible, it says). "If you searched on 'Michael Phelps' in 2001, for instance, you were probably looking for the scie...
docs.lead_paragraph: History | For its 10th birthday, Google offers a way to look back at Web history using its 2001 page index (the earliest index accessible, it says). "If you searched on 'Michael Phelps' in 2001, for instance, you were probably looking for the scientist, not the swimmer, 'ipod' didn't refer to a music player, and 'youtube' didn't refer to much of anything. [Google]

docs.snippet: Google thrives by cutting fat, Facebook mulls a music service and more....
docs.lead_paragraph: In so many ways, Google does not operate in the same universe the rest of us do. The atmosphere in its world is so infused with money from the company's singular advertising model that normal rules of physics don't apply in the way we are used to. Notice how Planet Google reacts to an economic earthquake: Initially, at least, hardly anything shakes. This and a few more headlines in today's Quick Bits.

headline.main: Quick Bits: Fat Times for Google, Lean Ones for Credit Thieves

docs.abstract: Google thrives by cutting fat, Facebook mulls a music service and more.

docs.lead_paragraph: Politics | The idea of the day seems to be the prospect of a Democratic supermajority (just Google it), prompted by today's Wall Street Journal editorial positing it as the ultimate conservative nightmare. In August, Michael Lind put this idea into historical context, arguing there's always been broad support for the New Deal's economically populist policies. But to achieve a truly epochal shift, the Democrats will have to welcome socially conservative economic populists. [Wall Street Journal, Salon]

headline.main: The Newer Deal: a Liberal Supermajority?

docs.snippet: In praise of Google Docs, a free Internet-based word processing application that also allows for offline use....
docs.lead_paragraph: I recently bought a MacBook Air so that I could have an ultra lightweight computer for traveling and for days when I need to work outside my home office. Because it's my second computer, I didn't want to spend money on software. Whenever I used it to create documents, I figured I'd just work in "the cloud," meaning that I'd store things on the Internet rather than on the computer's hard drive. I was already a heavy user of Google Docs, a free word-processing application that allows users to easily share documents with other people. So I thought I'd just use that as my word processing program on the new computer. Then I started worrying -- did I really want to rely on being able to get Internet access every time I wanted to work on a document?

headline.main: Computing in the Cloud, With Suspenders

docs.abstract: In praise of Google Docs, a free Internet-based word processing application that also allows for offline use.

docs.snippet: Google may not have to bail out Yahoo, smartphones squeeze carrier profits and more....
docs.lead_paragraph: The trend for the day: mixed blessings. For example, the phone companies are selling more smartphones at lower profit margins. On the other hand, Netflix is selling fewer new subscriptions at higher profit margins. You might even call the seeming reluctance of the Justice Department to okay Yahoo's deal to have Google sell some of its ads a mixed blessing, at least for Google. Now that Microsoft doesn't seem to want to buy Yahoo, a blocked deal could leave Yahoo, Google's biggest rival, to wither with no savior in sight.

headline.main: Quick Bits: Google's Bailout of Yahoo and More

docs.snippet: The new "Googlephone" is in the iPhone's shadow....
docs.lead_paragraph: I wandered down to the T-Mobile store at Ninth Avenue and 43rd Street in New York City to see what kind of crowds - if any - were lining up to buy the new T-Mobile G1 which went on sale Wednesday. No lines out the door. No crowding at the counter. Just a couple talking to a salesman who too was figuring out how to work the new mobile phone which is powered by Google's new Android operating system.

docs.snippet: After another week of intense discussions, the Google-Yahoo advertising partnership isn't dead yet....
docs.lead_paragraph: It's been no secret that the advertising partnership between Google and Yahoo is in a great deal of trouble. The Justice Department, which has been investigating the deal for weeks, has raised concerns about its effect on competition. The companies have agreed to postpone its implementation multiple times, to give regulators more time to finish their investigation, and to see if they can reach a compromise that would address those concerns.

headline.main: Google-Yahoo Ad Deal Remains in Limbo

docs.abstract: After another week of intense discussions, the Google-Yahoo advertising partnership isn't dead yet.
